title.narrative: Improving productivity of members yield through farm management and succession planning.

description.narrative:
Kibinge Coffee Farmers’ Cooperative Society (KCFCS) is a registered primary cooperative society operating in Kibinge Sub-county in Bukomansimbi District within the greater Masaka sub-region.  KCFCS started in 1995 as a company limited by guarantee.  In 2009 KCFCS was transformed into a cooperative society and registered with the Ministry of Trade Industry and co-operatives.  The Co-operative society became a Fair-Trade (FT) certified coffee producer in 2011 before being registered as a coffee exporter in Uganda in 2012. 

The membership of Kibinge is increasing every year in 2018 members were 1680 by the end of 2019 it has increased to 2012. Kibinge have an aging member population. This has posed a threat to the cooperative supply base land fragmentation and the growing capacity of the cooperative. In 2017 Kibinge initiated the farm management practice for members focusing the aging members to improve their productivity by outsourcing the farming practices to farm supervisors recruited by Kibinge. This would give them hope during their retirement period when they are no longer physically strong to manage their farms gainfully and continue earning a good living simultaneously fulfilling the required supply for the coffee business of Kibinge. After two consecutive years of piloting the overall objective of the initiative has been to promote standardized farming practices leading to better coffee production and its quality for a reliable supply base. This pilot has opened a new insight that through farm management members have benefited from productivity and quality yields.

This action plan will help in expanding the farm management practice. It will also address the succession issues of member's farms which is highly connected with aging issues. Kibinge's aspires to transform at least 30% of the members to middle-income economic status by 2025 this action plan will attempt to contribute to the objective.

Upscale farm management initiative by 25 reach 107 members 

Train 240 farmers on GAP to improve their productivity. 

Train 100 members on farm succession plannig
